item.title: WTA Finals tennis: Sabalenka v Pegula; Gauff beats ailing Paolini in straight sets ‚Äì live
item.description:
Updates from the group-stage matches in Riyadh
Gauff‚Äôs second serve key to success | Email Yara

Gauff 3-1 Paolini* (* denotes server): Gauff nets two backhands in a row as the Italian plays her first ball with a bit more power than in the first three games. But Guaff uses the court to make Paolini chase the ball at the baseline and gets to deuce after a weak second serve from the Italian. The two trade advantages for a while and at the fifth deuce, Gauff nets a backhand return. Paolini finally sees out the 8min 58sec game after Gauff sends one long.

*Gauff 3-0 Paolini (* denotes server): A long rally ends with the Italian powerfully slicing a winner and following it up with another crosscourt forehand that Gauff strains to reach. But she sends three returns long in back-to-back break points, putting her arms up in the air in frustration. Gauff gets the advantage and turns the game around to take the set after another poor return from Paolini, this one going into the stands.

Continue reading...

**Gauff 3-1 Paolini\* (\* denotes server):** Gauff nets two backhands in a row as the Italian plays her first ball with a bit more power than in the first three games. But Guaff uses the court to make Paolini chase the ball at the baseline and gets to deuce after a weak second serve from the Italian. The two trade advantages for a while and at the fifth deuce, Gauff nets a backhand return. Paolini finally sees out the 8min 58sec game after Gauff sends one long.
**\*Gauff 3-0 Paolini (\* denotes server):** A long rally ends with the Italian powerfully slicing a winner and following it up with another crosscourt forehand that Gauff strains to reach. But she sends three returns long in back-to-back break points, putting her arms up in the air in frustration. Gauff gets the advantage and turns the game around to take the set after another poor return from Paolini, this one going into the stands.

item.title: Prop 50: Californians vote on redistricting to counter redrawn Texas maps
item.description:
Ballot measure would let legislature redraw congressional districts to carve out five more Democratic seats

Californians headed to the polls on Tuesday to decide on Proposition 50, a ballot measure of national significance that could play a major role in determining which party controls the US House of Representatives after the 2026 midterms.

If voters approve the proposal, the state will halt the work of its independent redistricting commission and allow the legislature to redraw congressional districts to carve out five additional Democratic congressional seats. The effort is a direct attempt to neutralize Texas‚Äôs partisan gerrymander, undertaken at the request of Donald Trump, to create several new safe Republican districts.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Ballot measure would let legislature redraw congressional districts to carve out five more Democratic seats
Californians headed to the polls on Tuesday to decide on Proposition 50, a ballot measure of national significance that could play a major role in determining which party controls the [US House of Representatives](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/house-of-representatives) after the 2026 midterms.
If voters approve the proposal, the state will halt the work of its independent redistricting commission and allow the legislature to redraw congressional districts to carve out five additional Democratic congressional seats. The effort is a direct attempt to neutralize [Texas](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/texas)‚Äôs partisan gerrymander, undertaken at the request of [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump), to create several new safe Republican districts.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/04/prop-50-california-redistricting-vote-maps-latest)

item.title: Dick Cheney, vice-president and giant of Republican politics, dies aged 84
item.description:
Cheney, who served under presidents from Nixon to George W Bush, will be remembered for controversial role after 9/11

Dick Cheney, the divisive US vice-president under George W Bush who helped lead the country into a disastrous invasion of Iraq, died on Monday, his family has said. He was 84.

Cheney at various times held the roles of member of Congress, White House chief of staff and secretary of defense, but it was as one of the country‚Äôs most powerful vice-presidents that he had the biggest impact, wielding great influence over the less experienced Bush.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Cheney, who served under presidents from Nixon to George W Bush, will be remembered for controversial role after 9/11
[Dick Cheney](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/dick-cheney), the divisive US vice-president under [George W Bush](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/george-bush) who helped lead the country into a disastrous invasion of [Iraq](https://www.theguardian.com/world/iraq), died on Monday, his family has said. He was 84.
Cheney at various times held the roles of member of Congress, White House chief of staff and secretary of defense, but it was as one of the country‚Äôs most powerful vice-presidents that he had the biggest impact, wielding great influence over the less experienced Bush.

item.title: Why pay $50 billion for the headache known as Tylenol?
item.description: Kimberly-Clark‚Äôs stock closed down 14% yesterday after it gambled nearly $50 billion on a company called Kenvue, maker of Listerine, Band-Aids, and Tylenol ‚Äî the painkiller HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy wants to link to autism, despite a lack of scientific evidence. People are now suing Kenvue, a potential liability that will become Kimberly-Clark's problem. We unpack. Also: potential changes to public service loan forgiveness and a speech by Federal Reserve Governor Lisa Cook.

item.title: Pennsylvania artist sorry for including Nazi camp arch on school parade float
item.description:
‚ÄòI made a mistake‚Äô says artist who included cloned archway on Halloween float for a Catholic school

A Pennsylvania artist‚Äôs efforts to create a Halloween float for a local Catholic school went awry when he inadvertently included a replica of the gateway arch from a Nazi concentration camp, prompting a hasty apology from the diocese of Harrisburg.

In apologizing for the fiasco, Galen Shelly told PennLive that a lighted archway and lanterns he ordered to decorate a parade float he was building for Hanover‚Äôs St Joseph‚Äôs school did not arrive in time ‚Äì so he searched the internet for images of cemetery gates to represent the idea that ‚Äúnone of us get out of this life alive‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
‚ÄòI made a mistake‚Äô says artist who included cloned archway on Halloween float for a Catholic school

In apologizing for the fiasco, Galen Shelly [told PennLive](https://www.pennlive.com/news/2025/11/holocaust-imagery-on-halloween-parade-float-designer-apologizes-for-mistake.html) that a lighted archway and lanterns he ordered to decorate a parade float he was building for Hanover‚Äôs St Joseph‚Äôs school did not arrive in time ‚Äì so he searched the internet for images of cemetery gates to represent the idea that ‚Äúnone of us get out of this life alive‚Äù.

item.title: Dick Cheney remains divisive in death, drawing tributes and condemnation
item.description:
Leaders from Bush to Barrasso paid tribute to the former vice-president, whose career drew praise and controversy

US political leaders offered their condolences in reaction to the news that Dick Cheney had died, with George W Bush describing his former vice-president as ‚Äúa calm and steady presence in the White House amid great national challenges‚Äù.

Bush wrote in a statement that he would remember Cheney ‚Äúfor the decent honorable man that he was‚Äù and that history would remember him ‚Äúas among the finest public servants of his generation ‚Äì a patriot who brought integrity, high intelligence and seriousness of purpose to every position he held‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: Listeria outbreak in pasta meals linked to six deaths across 18 US states
item.description:
Listeria found in pasta sold by Trader Joe‚Äôs, Kroger and others as CDC urges people to check fridges and seek care if ill

Six people have died and several dozen have been hospitalized across the US after an outbreak of listeria in precooked pasta meals.

The outbreak was first declared in June, leading to a wave of recalls of the pasta meals. It has now spread, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), which recently said that six people have died and 25 have been hospitalized across 18 states.

FreshRealm‚Äôs Home Chef Chicken Fettuccine Alfredo 12.5-oz (sold at Kroger and Walmart)

FreshRealm‚Äôs Marketside Grilled Chicken Alfredo with Fettuccine 12.3-oz and 32.8-oz (sold at Kroger and Walmart)

FreshRealm‚Äôs Marketside Linguine with Beef Meatballs & Marinara Sauce 12-oz. (sold at Walmart)

Albertsons Companies store-made deli pasta salads (sold under multiple brand names including Albertsons, Safeway and Vons)

Trader Joe‚Äôs Cajun Style Blackened Chicken Breast Fettuccine Alfredo 16-oz plastic tray packages

Demer Food Group‚Äôs Scott & Jon‚Äôs Shrimp Scampi with Linguini Bowls 9.6-oz

Kroger deli bowtie and penne pasta salads

Giant Eagle smoked mozzarella pasta salad

Sprouts Farmers Market smoked mozzarella pasta salad

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Listeria found in pasta sold by Trader Joe‚Äôs, Kroger and others as CDC urges people to check fridges and seek care if ill
Six people have died and several dozen have been hospitalized across the [US](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news) after an outbreak of listeria in precooked pasta meals.
The outbreak was first declared in June, leading to a wave of recalls of the pasta meals. It has now spread, [according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)](https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/chicken-fettuccine-alfredo-06-25/index.html), which recently said that six people have died and 25 have been hospitalized across 18 states.
[FreshRealm‚Äôs Home Chef Chicken Fettuccine Alfredo](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/freshrealm-recalls-chicken-fettuccine-alfredo-products-due-possible-listeria) 12.5-oz (sold at Kroger and Walmart)
[FreshRealm‚Äôs Marketside Grilled Chicken Alfredo with Fettuccine](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/freshrealm-recalls-chicken-fettuccine-alfredo-products-due-possible-listeria) 12.3-oz and 32.8-oz (sold at Kroger and Walmart)
[FreshRealm‚Äôs Marketside Linguine with Beef Meatballs & Marinara Sauce](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/fsis-issues-public-health-alert-ready-eat-meals-containing-pasta-may-be-contaminated) 12-oz. (sold at Walmart)
[Albertsons Companies store-made deli pasta salads](https://www.fda.gov/safety/recalls-market-withdrawals-safety-alerts/update-albertsons-companies-voluntarily-recalls-select-store-made-deli-items-containing-bowtie-pasta) (sold under multiple brand names including Albertsons, Safeway and Vons)
[Trader Joe‚Äôs Cajun Style Blackened Chicken Breast Fettuccine Alfredo](https://www.fsis.usda.gov/recalls-alerts/fsis-issues-public-health-alert-ready-eat-meals-containing-pasta-may-be-contaminated) 16-oz plastic tray packages
[Demer Food Group‚Äôs](https://www.fda.gov/safety/recalls-market-withdrawals-safety-alerts/demers-food-group-voluntarily-recalls-select-scott-jons-shrimp-scampi-linguini-bowls-due-ingredient) Scott & Jon‚Äôs Shrimp Scampi with Linguini Bowls 9.6-oz
[Kroger deli bowtie and penne pasta salads](https://www.fda.gov/safety/recalls-market-withdrawals-safety-alerts/kroger-voluntarily-recalls-two-varieties-deli-pasta-salads-because-possible-health-risk)
[Giant Eagle smoked mozzarella pasta salad](https://www.fda.gov/safety/recalls-market-withdrawals-safety-alerts/giant-eagle-recalls-smoked-mozzarella-pasta-salad-due-potential-listeria-monocytogenes-contamination)
[Sprouts Farmers Market smoked mozzarella pasta salad](https://www.fda.gov/safety/recalls-market-withdrawals-safety-alerts/sprouts-farmers-market-recalling-smoked-mozzarella-pasta-salad-because-possible-health-risk)
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/04/listeria-outbreak-deaths-pasta-kroger-trader-joes)

item.title: Judge considers Democratic challenge to Trump troop deployment in Memphis
item.description:
City government declines to raise objection in court but state leaders and ACLU seek to block deployment of troops

A state court in Nashville on Monday heard a legal challenge by some Democratic elected officials to Donald Trump‚Äôs deployment of the national guard into the streets of Memphis, notable in part because of who has not raised an objection: the city of Memphis itself.

Shelby county‚Äôs mayor, Lee Harris, led the lawsuit, along with state representatives Gabby Salinas and GA Hardaway, both Memphis Democrats. Other state and local leaders joined the suit, including one Memphis city council member. The ACLU later filed briefs in support of the suit seeking an injunction to block the deployment of troops.

Continue reading...

Shelby county‚Äôs mayor, Lee Harris, led the lawsuit, along with state representatives Gabby Salinas and GA Hardaway, both Memphis Democrats. Other state and local leaders joined the suit, including one Memphis city council member. The ACLU later filed briefs in support of the suit seeking an injunction to block the deployment of troops.

item.title: Could a win on California‚Äôs Prop 50 aid Gavin Newsom‚Äôs presidential hopes?
item.description:
The ballot measure win would be a significant political gain for the Golden state governor eyeing the White House

Gavin Newsom, the California governor, is on the verge of a political victory that, just a few months ago, didn‚Äôt exist.

In August, a group of Texas Democrats fled their state to block Republicans from approving a rare mid-decade gerrymander to redraw congressional districts at Donald Trump‚Äôs urging. Altering the maps in the GOP‚Äôs favor would make it even harder for Democrats to take back control of Congress in the midterm elections next year. The Texas Democrats hoped their standoff would be a national call to action.

Continue reading...

In August, a group of Texas Democrats fled their state to block Republicans from approving a rare mid-decade gerrymander to redraw congressional districts at Donald Trump‚Äôs urging. item.title: California father who killed his baby son sentenced to more than 30 years in prison
item.description:
Jake Haro and his wife had reported the baby kidnapped outside a store, drawing widespread attention and a public search

A southern California father who pleaded guilty to killing his missing seven-month-old son was sentenced Monday to more than 30 years in prison.

Jake Haro, 32, was sentenced after he pleaded guilty in October to the second-degree murder of his son, Emmanuel, the Riverside county district attorney‚Äôs office said in a statement. A months-long investigation has failed to locate the child‚Äôs remains.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs this buzz of excitement‚Äô: Emily Fox on USWNT and Arsenal ambitions
item.description:
Right-back discusses Emma Hayes‚Äôs tactical messages, new blood in the national team and how Champions League win changed her

Emily Fox made her 68th appearance for the United States in the first of two recent friendlies against Portugal and the Arsenal right-back has been a steady hand for Emma Hayes.

Hayes has her eye on the 2027 World Cup after winning Olympic gold 15 months ago, and has used 2025 to evolve and evaluate the pool of players. Over the course of 10 wins and three defeats in that timeframe, Fox has been a dynamic force difficult to dislodge from the right flank of a new project. Her speed and skill are essential to the team‚Äôs defence and intrinsic to their attack.

Continue reading...

item.title: How shifting tariff policy hits one Pennsylvania business
item.description: Oral arguments over the Trump administration's "reciprocal tariffs" are set for tomorrow, in a test over limits to a president's power to act without Congress. Whichever way the high court decides, however, the co-founder of True Places, a Pennsylvania-based folding camp chair company, thinks that likely won't be the end of the tariff rollercoaster. Plus, Norway's massive sovereign wealth fund has voted against Elon Musk‚Äôs pay package from Tesla. Why?

item.title: Starbucks stirs things up in China
item.description: From the BBC World Service: Starbucks is selling the majority stake of its business in China to investment firm Boyu Capital as part of a $4 billion deal. The global coffee brand hopes the funds will help kick-start growth in the face of growing local competition. Then, it's a big week for Tesla, as vote results are expected on Elon Musk's proposed $1 trillion pay package. But Norway's sovereign public wealth fund, a major investor, stated it's opposing the deal.

item.title: How Trump is weaponizing the DoJ to ‚Äòbully, prosecute, punish and silence‚Äô his foes
item.description:
President‚Äôs pressure on the department to prosecute his enemies is hurting US law and violating policies, say experts

Donald Trump‚Äôs intense pressure on the US Department of Justice (DoJ) to charge key foes with crimes based on dubious evidence and his ongoing investigations of other political enemies is hurting the rule of law in the US and violating departmental policies, which scholars and ex-prosecutors say may help scuttle some charges.

They also voice dismay about charges filed against ex-FBI director James Comey and Letitia James, the New York attorney general, by Lindsey Halligan, the ex-White House lawyer and novice prosecutor, who Trump installed in a key US attorney post after forcing out a veteran prosecutor who deemed the cases weak.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump administration to fund just half of food stamp benefits | First Thing
item.description:
Department of Agriculture using contingency funds to keep benefits going amid government shutdown. Plus, economists warn $70tn in inherited wealth over next decade will widen inequality

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

The Trump administration said it would provide only partial relief to recipients of food stamps on Monday, amid mounting uncertainty among the nearly 42 million people on the supplemental nutrition assistance program (Snap).

How did we get here? As a result of the shutdown, Donald Trump has threatened to cut off the food benefits for the first time in the program‚Äôs more than 60-year history. A federal judge last week prevented the Department of Agriculture from suspending Snap altogether.

What impact will it have? There have already been long lines at food banks across the nation. Chris Stein spoke to people affected, with many saying they would have to scrimp on food to get by. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dumbfounded by the cruelty,‚Äù one said.

Can Trump even do that? The president does not directly determine how much money any city receives from the federal government; appropriation is the constitutional function of Congress. But control over how money is spent ‚Äì or withheld in acts of impoundment, which are forbidden under federal law ‚Äì has become a point of legal contention.

What do New York polls say? A recent survey from AtlasIntel showed Mamdani, the Democratic nominee, on 44%, the independent Andrew Cuomo on 39% and the Republican Curtis Sliwa on 16%.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Department of Agriculture using contingency funds to keep benefits going amid government shutdown. Plus, economists warn $70tn in inherited wealth over next decade will widen inequality
- [**Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here**](https://www.theguardian.com/info/2018/sep/17/guardian-us-morning-briefing-sign-up-to-stay-informed)
Good morning.
The Trump administration said it would provide only partial relief to recipients of food stamps on Monday, amid mounting uncertainty among the nearly 42 million people on the supplemental nutrition assistance program (Snap).
**How did we get here?** As a result of the shutdown, Donald Trump has threatened to cut off the food benefits for the first time in the program‚Äôs more than 60-year history. A federal judge last week prevented the Department of Agriculture from [suspending](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/31/judge-blocks-trump-snap-suspension) Snap altogether.
**What impact will it have?** There have already been long lines at food banks across the nation. Chris Stein [spoke to people](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/trump-snap-benefits-reactions) affected, with many saying they would have to scrimp on food to get by. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dumbfounded by the cruelty,‚Äù one said.
**Can Trump even do that?** The president does not directly determine how much money any city receives from the federal government; appropriation is the constitutional function of Congress. But control over how money is spent ‚Äì or withheld in acts of impoundment, which are forbidden under federal law ‚Äì has become a point of [legal contention](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/trump-mamdani-new-york-election-mayor-cuomo).
**What do New York polls say?** A recent survey from [AtlasIntel](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/polls/nyc-mayoral-election-polls-2025.html) showed Mamdani, the Democratic nominee, on 44%, the independent Andrew Cuomo on 39% and the Republican Curtis Sliwa on 16%.

item.title: Women‚Äôs soccer faces plenty of serious threats. So why the panic about trans players? | Lesley Ryder
item.description:
Angel City‚Äôs Elizabeth Eddy was rebuked by her own teammates for an op-ed on trans players. It‚Äôs easy to understand their objections

On 26 October, Angel City FC‚Äôs Elizabeth Eddy made her first post on X in nearly two years. In it, Eddy in essence responded to the Guardian‚Äôs report that the NWSL had quietly dropped its inclusion policy for trans and intersex athletes, leaving the league‚Äôs future stance on the matter undecided.

The New York Post gave Eddy‚Äôs writing a signal boost the next day, republishing it in full.

Lesley Ryder is a writer and host covering women‚Äôs soccer in Chicagoland.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Angel City‚Äôs Elizabeth Eddy was rebuked by her own teammates for an op-ed on trans players. It‚Äôs easy to understand their objections
On 26 October, Angel City FC‚Äôs Elizabeth Eddy made her first post on X in nearly two years. In it, Eddy in essence responded to the Guardian‚Äôs report that the NWSL had [quietly dropped](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2025/jul/15/nwsl-and-us-soccers-lack-of-transgender-policy-targeted-by-conservative-lobby-groups) its inclusion policy for trans and intersex athletes, leaving the league‚Äôs future stance on the matter undecided.
The New York Post gave Eddy‚Äôs writing a signal boost the next day, [republishing it in full](https://nypost.com/2025/10/27/opinion/national-womens-soccer-league-must-adopt-gender-standards-to-keep-growing/).
_Lesley Ryder is a writer and host covering women‚Äôs soccer in Chicagoland._

item.title: New York City voters head to polls for closely watched mayoral election
item.description:
Race has gained national attention with Trump threatening to pull federal funds from the city if Zohran Mamdani wins

  • Live NYC mayoral election results: Zohran Mamdani, Andrew Cuomo and Curtis Sliwa face off

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

New York City voters are heading to the polls on Tuesday in one of the most closely watched mayoral elections in the city‚Äôs history.

Vying for the city‚Äôs top office are Zohran Mamdani, the 34-year-old democratic socialist and state assemblymember from Queens who is the Democratic nominee; Andrew Cuomo, the former Democratic governor running as an independent after losing to Mamdani in June‚Äôs primary; and Curtis Sliwa, the Republican candidate and founder of the Guardian Angels, a non-profit organization dedicated to ‚Äúunarmed crime prevention‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: Sora 2's disinformation problem
item.description:
OpenAI‚Äôs latest AI video generator Sora 2 has gotten a lot of attention for its realistic creations. The tool is supposed to have guardrails to prevent creating videos based on misinformation.


But new analysis from watchdog group Newsguard found that, when prompted, Sora 2 often generated videos based on lies, such as false claims having to do with election fraud in a foreign country or that a toddler was detained by immigration agents.


Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo spoke with Sofia Rubinson, senior editor at Newsguard, to learn more.
item.source:markdown:
OpenAI‚Äôs latest AI video generator Sora 2 has gotten a lot of attention for its realistic creations. The tool is supposed to have guardrails to prevent creating videos based on misinformation.
But new analysis from watchdog group Newsguard found that, when prompted, Sora 2 often generated videos based on lies, such as false claims having to do with election fraud in a foreign country or that a toddler was detained by immigration agents.
Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo spoke with Sofia Rubinson, senior editor at Newsguard, to learn more.

item.title: Shortage of prescription painkillers in Canada expected to last until 2026
item.description: Canadian pharmacists say a shortage of medications that contain oxycodone is expected to continue into the new year, while supply of another type of painkiller has increased since a countrywide disruption in the summer.

item.title: Win or lose at the Supreme Court, Trump has other tariff tools at his disposal
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court takes on a major case on Wednesday when it decides if President Donald Trump has the authority to use a law usually cited in emergencies for the imposition of tariffs on other countries. While they may not be as blunt as the law Trump has cited, there are a handful of other laws the president can cite to utilize tariffs for leverage and revenue.
item.source:markdown:
![An older cleanshaven blonde-haired man wearing a suit and yellow tie is shown speaking in closeup.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/0f6713bc-9fe6-448a-894e-0ce85d246f66,1762269509261/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C7179%2C4038%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The U.S. Supreme Court takes on a major case on Wednesday when it decides if President Donald Trump has the authority to use a law usually cited in emergencies for the imposition of tariffs on other countries. While they may not be as blunt as the law Trump has cited, there are a handful of other laws the president can cite to utilize tariffs for leverage and revenue.

item.title: Victor Conte, architect of infamous sport steroids scandal, dies aged 75
item.description:
• Balco boss revealed Marion Jones used growth hormones

  • Conte served four months in prison over involvement

Victor Conte, the architect of a scheme to provide undetectable performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes including the baseball stars Barry Bonds and Jason Giambi and the Olympic track champion Marion Jones decades ago, has died. He was 75.

The federal government‚Äôs investigation into a company Conte founded, the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative (Balco), yielded the convictions of Jones, the elite sprint cyclist Tammy Thomas and the former NFL defensive lineman Dana Stubblefield, along with coaches, distributors, a trainer, a chemist and a lawyer.

Continue reading...

item.title: The trouble with US veterans benefits isn‚Äôt ‚Äòrampant‚Äô fraud ‚Äì it‚Äôs bureaucratic roadblocks, advocates say
item.description:
Veterans groups say recent Washington Post stories on VA disability payments paint a misleading picture. The paper stands by its reporting

In October, the Washington Post reported that it had uncovered ‚Äúrampant exaggeration and fraud‚Äù in the US Department of Veterans Affairs‚Äô disability benefits system.

‚ÄúMilitary veterans are swamping the US government with dubious disability claims ‚Ä¶ exploiting the country‚Äôs sacred commitment to compensate those harmed in the line of duty,‚Äù the newspaper reported.

Continue reading...

item.title: Democrats fight to rebuild in key state races on election day
item.description:
With polls showing signs of recovery after a popularity slump, Tuesday‚Äôs results will test whether the party can regain voters‚Äô trust

One year after Donald Trump won his way back into the White House, voters are going back to the ballot box in a test of the president‚Äôs popularity and whether Democrats are able to rebound from their catastrophic losses of 2024.

With governor‚Äôs mansions, mayoral offices, statehouses and mid-cycle redistricting on the line in closely watched contests from Trenton, New Jersey and Richmond, Virginia to New York City and beyond, the party is pinning its hopes on locally rooted campaigns aiming to blunt a national conservative message that has surged in recent years.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
With polls showing signs of recovery after a popularity slump, Tuesday‚Äôs results will test whether the party can regain voters‚Äô trust
One year after [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) won his way back into the White House, voters are going back to the ballot box in a test of the president‚Äôs popularity and whether Democrats are able to rebound from their catastrophic losses of 2024.
With governor‚Äôs mansions, mayoral offices, statehouses and mid-cycle redistricting on the line in closely watched contests from Trenton, New Jersey and Richmond, Virginia to New York City and beyond, the party is pinning its hopes on locally rooted campaigns aiming to blunt a national conservative message that has surged in recent years.

item.title: Andrew Wiggins: how a shy NBA player negotiated growing up a star in the social media era
item.description:
In an extract from his new book on the rise of Canadian basketball, Oren Weisfeld examines the pressures of being a teenage star in the modern game

Andrew Wiggins was among the first superstar prospects of the social media era. Born in Thornhill, Ontario just north of Toronto, Wiggins was known internationally by the time he was 13. It wasn‚Äôt always easy for the shy, small-town kid to embrace the spotlight.

After just one full season at Vaughan, Wiggins needed better competition than Canada could provide and moved on to Huntington Prep in Huntington, West Virginia ‚Äî a relatively new prep school set in a small, blue-collar, sports-oriented college town near Kansas.

This is an edited extract from The Golden Generation: How Canada Became a Basketball Powerhouse by Oren Weisfeld. It‚Äôs published by ECW Press for $19.95 (USD) wherever you get your books.

Continue reading...

item.title: E-borrowing exceeds print at Vancouver libraries ‚Äî can it keep up with the cost?
item.description: For the first time in its history, loans of digital materials, such as e-books, e-magazines and music, have exceeded those of physical copies at the library, although online facsimiles cost three to five times as much.

item.title: At least 26 dead after Typhoon Kalmaegi barrels through Philippines
item.description: Typhoon Kalmaegi has left at least 26 people dead in the Philippines, mostly in flooding set off by the storm, which barrelled across the central part of the country on Tuesday, disaster response officials said.

item.title: Jacoby Brissett steps up for Cardinals to sink Cowboys and end losing streak
item.description:
• Kyler Murray said to be not ready after foot problems

  • Dallas fall to 3-5-1 as Arizona move to 3-5 with win

Jacoby Brissett had a stock answer ready for the question of whether the Arizona quarterback has done enough to be the replacement, not just the fill-in, for Kyler Murray. The coach, Jonathan Gannon, barely had an answer at all. The Cardinals will worry about what appears to be a full-blown controversy later. For now, they will enjoy ending a five-game losing streak.

Brissett threw for two touchdowns and ran for a score in another game with Murray sidelined by a foot injury, and the Cardinals beat the Dallas Cowboys 27-17 on Monday night. Brissett made his third consecutive start after the week began with expectations of Murray returning coming off the team‚Äôs open week.

Continue reading...

item.title: What‚Äôs an ‚ÄòAlberta whisky‚Äô? The province wants to spell it out in law

item.title: Cuban government stealing wages from its citizens in Canada, say ex-workers
item.description: Former workers of a joint venture between the government of Cuba and Canadian mining company Sherritt International say they were victims of a wage confiscation scheme that left them to live on just a fraction of their nominal salaries. They also say they were forced to attend Communist Party meetings and provide reports on all interactions with their Canadian colleagues.

item.title: Senate Republicans strike down Democratic proposal to fully fund Snap
item.description:
Democratic leaders decry ‚Äòunbelievably cruel‚Äô move, saying ‚ÄòTrump is using food as a weapon‚Äô during shutdown

Senate Republicans shot down a Democratic-led attempt to fully fund Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits on Monday during the government shutdown ‚Äì a move that heightens uncertainty for the 42 million Americans participating in the country‚Äôs biggest anti-hunger program.

Jeff Merkley, a Democratic senator, and Chuck Schumer, the Senate Democratic leader, attempted to pass a resolution via unanimous consent that would have forced the Department of Agriculture to fund Snap benefits for the month of November.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Democratic leaders decry ‚Äòunbelievably cruel‚Äô move, saying ‚ÄòTrump is using food as a weapon‚Äô during shutdown
Senate [Republicans](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/republicans) shot down a Democratic-led attempt to fully fund Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits on Monday during the government shutdown ‚Äì a move that heightens uncertainty for the 42 million Americans participating in the country‚Äôs biggest anti-hunger program.
Jeff Merkley, a Democratic senator, and Chuck Schumer, the Senate Democratic leader, attempted to pass a [resolution](https://www.merkley.senate.gov/wp-content/uploads/Merkley-Schumer-SNAP-Resolution.pdf) via unanimous consent that would have forced the Department of Agriculture to fund Snap benefits for the month of November.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/senate-republicans-snap-funds-resolution)

item.title: Americans ‚Äòdumbfounded by cruelty‚Äô of Trump officials slashing Snap benefits
item.description:
Those among the 42 million enrolled in the program worry that cutoff of the benefit will send their lives into a tailspin

Across the country, Americans who depend on government help to buy groceries are preparing for the worst.

As a result of the ongoing federal government shutdown, Donald Trump has threatened to, for the first time in the program‚Äôs more than 60-year history, cut off benefits provided by the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance program (Snap). A federal judge last week prevented the US Department of Agriculture from suspending Snap altogether, but the Trump administration now says enrollees will receive only half of their usual benefits.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Those among the 42 million enrolled in the program worry that cutoff of the benefit will send their lives into a tailspin
Across the country, Americans who depend on government help to buy groceries are preparing for the worst.
As a result of the ongoing federal government shutdown, Donald Trump has threatened to, for the first time in the program‚Äôs more than 60-year history, cut off benefits provided by the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance program (Snap). A federal judge last week prevented the US Department of Agriculture from [suspending Snap altogether](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/31/judge-blocks-trump-snap-suspension), but the Trump administration now says enrollees [will receive only half](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/trump-partially-fund-food-stamps-snap) of their usual benefits.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/trump-snap-benefits-reactions)

item.title: How long until SNAP reaches kitchen tables?
item.description:
The Trump administration has been court ordered to partially fund this month‚Äôs SNAP benefits, after refusing to step in during the shutdown. Emergency USDA funds will cover about half of the $8 billion spent each month on the food assistance program. But it‚Äôs unclear how long households could wait for the partial benefits to kick in. Also in this episode: The manufacturing sector appears to be ‚Äúmeh,‚Äù OPEC ups production despite global oil glut, and the U.S. races to catch up on rare earth elements.

item.title: Trump administration says it will partially fund Snap food aid benefits‚Äì live
item.description:
Trump administration says in court filing it plans to use emergency funds to partially cover November Snap benefits for millions of Americans

  • Trump administration will provide half of usual funds to Snap recipients in November

Looking ahead, on Wednesday, the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal. It‚Äôs set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump‚Äôs presidential power in his second term.

My colleague, Eduardo Porter, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president‚Äôs contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several ‚Äúthreats‚Äù facing the US.

Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to levy a tariff ‚Äì a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.

IEEPA gives the president authority ‚Äúto deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat‚Äù.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Trump administration says in court filing it plans to use emergency funds to partially cover November Snap benefits for millions of Americans
- [Trump administration will provide half of usual funds to Snap recipients in November](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/trump-partially-fund-food-stamps-snap)
Looking ahead, on Wednesday, **the supreme court will hear arguments on whether Donald Trump‚Äôs sweeping tariffs on dozens of countries are legal.** It‚Äôs set to be one of the most consequential rulings on the expanse of Trump‚Äôs presidential power in his second term.
My colleague, **Eduardo Porter**, has this helpful breakdown on the question at the heart of this case. A dozen states have challenged the president‚Äôs contention that the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) of 1977 gives him the power to impose tariffs on imports from every country in the world to defend the nation from a several ‚Äúthreats‚Äù facing the US.
Justices will focus much of their attention on whether IEEPA authorizes the president to [levy a tariff](https://ag.ny.gov/sites/default/files/court-filings/state-of-oregon-et-al-v-donald-j-trump-united-states-department-of-homeland-security-et-al-complaint-2025.pdf) ‚Äì a word that is not mentioned in the text of the law and is, moreover, a form of taxation, over which, per the constitution, Congress has exclusive power.
IEEPA [gives the president](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/50/1701) authority ‚Äúto deal with any unusual and extraordinary threat, which has its source in whole or substantial part outside the United States, to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States, if the president declares a national emergency with respect to such threat‚Äù.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/nov/03/us-government-shutdown-donald-trump-latest-politics-news)

item.title: Trial starts for DC man charged with throwing sandwich at federal agent
item.description:
A video that went viral captured Sean Charles Dunn hurling his sandwich at a Customs and Border Protection agent outside a nightclub

Throwing a sandwich at a federal agent turned Sean Charles Dunn into a symbol of resistance against Donald Trump‚Äôs law-enforcement surge in the nation‚Äôs capital. This week, federal prosecutors are trying to persuade a jury of fellow Washington DC residents that Dunn simply broke the law.

That could be a tough sell for the government in a city that has chafed against Trump‚Äôs federal takeover, which is entering its third month. A grand jury refused to indict Dunn on a felony assault count before the office of Jeanine Pirro, a US attorney, opted to charge him instead with a misdemeanor.

Continue reading...

A video that went viral captured Sean Charles Dunn hurling his sandwich at a Customs and Border Protection agent outside a nightclub
Throwing a sandwich at a federal agent turned Sean Charles Dunn into a symbol of resistance against [Donald Trump‚Äôs](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) law-enforcement surge in the nation‚Äôs capital. This week, federal prosecutors are trying to persuade a jury of fellow Washington DC residents that Dunn simply broke the law.
That could be a tough sell for the government in a city that has chafed against Trump‚Äôs federal takeover, which is entering its third month. A grand jury refused to indict Dunn on a felony assault count before the office of Jeanine Pirro, a US attorney, opted to charge him instead with a misdemeanor.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/trial-sandwich-assault-case)

item.title: Commanders coach accepts blame for leaving Jayden Daniels in game before serious injury
item.description:
• Dan Quinn says decision is ‚Äò100% on me‚Äô

  • Washington QB suffered dislocated elbow

Washington Commanders head coach Dan Quinn has accepted he shares some of the blame for a serious injury to the team‚Äôs quarterback, Jayden Daniels.

Daniels, who had one of the greatest rookie campaigns of all time last season, suffered a dislocated left elbow in Sunday‚Äôs loss to the Seattle Seahawks. Although Daniels throws with his right arm, the injury has left his season in doubt. The injury was serious enough that the television broadcast did not show replays and several players turned away as Daniels was treated my medical staff.

Continue reading...

item.title: Mississippi woman fatally shoots monkey escaped from overturned truck
item.description:
Jessica Bond Ferguson said her 16-year-old told her about animal in the yard and she shot it to ‚Äòprotect her children‚Äô

One of the monkeys that escaped after a truck overturned on a Mississippi roadway on 28 October was shot and killed early on Sunday by a homeowner who said she feared for the safety of her children.

Jessica Bond Ferguson said she was alerted early on Sunday by her 16-year-old son who said he thought he had seen a monkey running in the yard outside their home near Heidelberg, Mississippi. She got out of bed, grabbed her firearm and her cellphone, and stepped outside where she saw the monkey about 60ft (18 meters) away.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump approval rating falls to second-term low of 37%
item.description:
New CNN/SSRS survey shows decline in president‚Äôs popularity as 68% of respondents say things going badly

Donald Trump‚Äôs approval rating has fallen to one of its lowest points, with only 37% of Americans expressing approval of his performance as president.

The new CNN/SSRS survey released on Monday shows a sharp decline in Trump‚Äôs approval ratings compared with the early days after he began his second term in January, when his approval stood at 47% by mid-February.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
New CNN/SSRS survey shows decline in president‚Äôs popularity as 68% of respondents say things going badly
Donald Trump‚Äôs approval rating has fallen to one of its lowest points, with only 37% of Americans expressing approval of his performance as president.
The new CNN/SSRS [survey](https://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/26211915/cnn-poll-trump-midterms-east-wing-parties.pdf) released on Monday shows a sharp decline in Trump‚Äôs approval ratings compared with the early days after he began his second term in January, when his approval [stood at](https://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/26211915/cnn-poll-trump-midterms-east-wing-parties.pdf) 47% by mid-February.

item.title: New York mayoral candidates campaign across city in final push before election
item.description:
Zohran Mamdani walked across Brooklyn Bridge while Andrew Cuomo headed to the Bronx

The candidates for New York City mayor spent a frantic final day campaigning across the city, as voters prepare to head to the polls on Tuesday in one of the most closely watched races in the city‚Äôs history.

Zohran Mamdani, the race‚Äôs frontrunner, whose campaign has been centered on affordability, has maintained a commanding lead, with most polls showing him leading by double digits.

Continue reading...

item.title: 'Tragic situation': Trump comments on former prince Andrew ‚Äì video

item.title: Trump administration will provide half of usual funds to Snap recipients in November
item.description:
Contingency funds will keep benefits going for nearly 42 million people in the food assistance program, says Trump

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

The Trump administration said it would provide partial relief to recipients of food stamps on Monday as the federal government shutdown approached a record-breaking length.

Amid mounting uncertainty among the nearly 42 million people on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap), the Department of Agriculture said it would use contingency funds to keep benefits going, albeit just 50% of the usual funds recipients receive on their cards.

Continue reading...

item.title: Terrorism charges filed over alleged Halloween plot targeting Michigan LGBTQ+ bars
item.description:
Authorities allege two men planned a Halloween-inspired attack motivated by Islamic State extremism

Two men have been charged with terrorism-related crimes in the Detroit area after federal authorities recently made arrests and seized a cache of weapons in a storage unit and elsewhere, officials said on Monday.

The men had scouted LGBTQ+ bars in Ferndale, a Detroit suburb, according to a 72-page criminal complaint unsealed in federal court.

Continue reading...

The ex-Duke of York, now known as Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, will also have to move out of his long-term residence at the Royal Lodge on the Windsor estate, Buckingham Palace announced on Thursday.

item.title: The ground is swallowing homes in this Native village in Alaska. Residents have no choice but to move
item.description:
The climate crisis is causing the permafrost to melt in Alaska, forcing the village of Nunapitchuk to relocate

Children splash gleefully in the river as adults cast fishing lines or head into the Alaska tundra to hunt. It‚Äôs a scene that has characterized summer days for centuries among the Yup‚Äôik people who have long lived in south-western Alaska, where the village of Nunapitchuk stands. But, with temperatures in Alaska warming nearly four times faster than most parts of the globe, that way of life is about to change.

Homes in Nunapitchuk have been sinking into the permafrost, and residents have decided their only choice is to move the entire village to higher ground.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
The climate crisis is causing the permafrost to melt in Alaska, forcing the village of Nunapitchuk to relocate
Children splash gleefully in the river as adults cast fishing lines or head into the [Alaska](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/alaska) tundra to hunt. It‚Äôs a scene that has characterized summer days for centuries among the Yup‚Äôik people who have long lived in south-western Alaska, where the village of Nunapitchuk stands. But, with temperatures in Alaska warming nearly four times faster than most parts of the globe, that way of life is about to change.
Homes in Nunapitchuk have been sinking into the [permafrost](https://nsidc.org/learn/parts-cryosphere/frozen-ground-permafrost), and residents have decided their only choice is to move the entire village to higher ground.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/03/alaska-nunapitchuk-climate-melting-permafrost)

item.title: Federal judge bars national guard troops in Portland, Oregon
item.description:
Judge ‚Äòfound no credible evidence‚Äô that protests grew out of control but final ruling to come Friday

A federal judge in Oregon on Sunday barred Donald Trump‚Äôs administration from deploying the national guard to Portland, Oregon, until at least Friday, saying she ‚Äúfound no credible evidence‚Äù that protests in the city grew out of control before the president federalized the troops earlier this fall.

The city and state sued in September to block the deployment.

item.title: Two girls injured in fall from ferris wheel at Louisiana fairground
item.description:
Pair were thrown to the ground after the bucket in which they were seated flipped over

Two girls were injured in a fall from a ferris wheel at a Louisiana fairground on Saturday, the latest in a series of similar episodes calling to question the safety of carnival and amusement park rides.

The pair were thrown to the ground after the bucket in which they were seated flipped over during the Harvest Festival event at New Roads, 30 miles north-west of Baton Rouge, Louisiana‚Äôs capital.

Continue reading...

item.title: Are Trump's "reciprocal" tariffs legal or not?
item.description: That's the question before the Supreme Court this week. President Donald Trump has been declaring an emergency and then using emergency authority to impose many of these tariffs. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is among those who've said they expect to prevail in the high court, but if they don't, there are other ways to apply taxes on goods from other countries. Also: BP shale asset sales and a dark side of the drug rehab industry.

item.title: ‚ÄòIn this ‚Äôtil the end‚Äô: Maine Senate hopeful Graham Platner on refusing to quit amid furor over ‚ÄòNazi‚Äô tattoo
item.description:
Platner‚Äôs populist campaign faces backlash over past comments and a contentious tattoo

On a recent Monday night, Graham Platner ‚Äì oysterman, army veteran and Democratic hopeful for US Senate ‚Äì took the stage in a small Maine town known for its oyster farming to assure voters that he was still in the game to win the Democratic primary, and ultimately unseat five-term Republican incumbent Susan Collins.

He addressed a crowd of 700, the most that could fit into the school gymnasium in Damariscotta, Maine before organizers had to start turning people away. As is typical for his campaign events, the gruff, plain-talking, flannel-clad, local business owner and former marine dissected the ‚Äúestablishment political system that serves the interests of the ultra wealthy‚Äù in front of a captivated audience.

Continue reading...

item.title: What hunger looks like in one state as SNAP starts to dry up
item.description: This past weekend, as the shutdown stretches on, funds for SNAP benefits began to dry up. The Treasury Secretary says payments could restart this week, and a federal court said the Trump administration must tap into emergency funds to get this done. Today, we'll check in with the Arkansas Hunger Relief Alliance for a snapshot of food insecurity there. Plus, Trump says he wants to fix Obamacare, and U.S. auto production could be hampered by a looming chip shortage.

item.title: Kimberly-Clark to buy Tylenol maker Kenvue in landmark $40bn merger
item.description:
Kleenex maker‚Äôs deal for troubled Johnson & Johnson spinoff comes amid lawsuits and regulatory scrutiny

Kleenex and Huggies maker Kimberly-Clark unveiled plans to buy Kenvue, the embattled consumer health conglomerate behind Tylenol, in a landmark deal for more than $40bn.

The blockbuster takeover comes weeks after Donald Trump claimed Tylenol heightens the risk of autism in children when it is used by pregnant women, an assertion hotly contested by scientists and contradicted by studies.

item.title: Top FDA official quits amid inquiry into ‚Äòserious concerns‚Äô over his conduct
item.description:
Lawsuit claims George Tidmarsh, head of FDA drug center, waged personal vendetta against pharmaceutical executive

The head of the US Food and Drug Administration‚Äôs drug center abruptly resigned on Sunday after federal officials began reviewing ‚Äúserious concerns about his personal conduct‚Äù, according to a government spokesperson.

Dr George Tidmarsh, who was named to the FDA post in July, was placed on leave on Friday after officials in the Department of Health and Human Services‚Äô (HHS) office of general counsel were notified of the issues, the HHS press secretary, Emily Hilliard, said in an email. Tidmarsh then resigned on Sunday morning.

Continue reading...

item.title: First Thing: Top 10 US billionaires‚Äô wealth grew by $698bn in past year
item.description:
Oxfam says Trump policies risk driving inequality to new heights while noting Democrats have also exacerbated wealth gap. Plus, why Salman Rushdie‚Äôs therapist has called him a ‚Äòbadass‚Äô

Good morning.

The collective wealth of the top 10 US billionaires has soared by $698bn in the past year, according to a report from Oxfam America on the growing wealth divide.

How have Trump‚Äôs policies affected the figures? Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúone big, beautiful bill‚Äù, passed by Congress in May, has been one of the ‚Äúsingle largest transfers of wealth upwards in decades‚Äù, according to the report, by cutting tax for the wealthy and corporations.

How does it work? The system, which launched more than a year ago, rewards soldiers who achieve strikes with points that can be exchanged to buy more weapons in an ‚ÄúAmazon-for-war‚Äù online store called Brave1 filled with more than 100 different drones, autonomous vehicles and other drone war material.

Continue reading...

item.title: One way to redefine the first lady role: demolish Melania‚Äôs office to build a folly
item.description:
The president‚Äôs wife is reported to have ‚Äòprivately raised concerns about‚Äô the destruction of the White House East Wing. If so, they were ignored

From Eleanor Roosevelt to Melania Trump, the East Wing of the White House served as a base for first ladies. It was where Michelle Obama spearheaded her Let‚Äôs Move public health campaign and where Nancy Reagan and her staff worked on the Just Say No drug awareness initiative.

‚ÄúIt was a place where first ladies could carry out the important work that they do,‚Äù said Katherine AS Sibley, a professor of history at St Joseph‚Äôs University.

item.title: Sam Bankman-Fried returns to court to challenge fraud verdict
item.description:
Sam Bankman-Fried, founder and former CEO of cryptocurrency exchange FTX, is serving 25 years in federal prison for fraud. His company collapsed and went bankrupt in 2022. Investigators found that billions of dollars in customer funds had been borrowed without permission to help shore up Bankman-Fried‚Äôs other firm, Alameda Research.


But throughout the last three years, Bankman-Fried has maintained his innocence, and he's filed an appeal. A hearing is scheduled for Nov. 4.


Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo spoke with Jonathan Jones, a reporter and producer for the investigative podcast ‚ÄúReveal,‚Äù who spent hours talking to the former CEO, FTX insiders and customers.
item.source:markdown:
Sam Bankman-Fried, founder and former CEO of cryptocurrency exchange FTX, is serving 25 years in federal prison for fraud. His company collapsed and went bankrupt in 2022. Investigators found that billions of dollars in customer funds had been borrowed without permission to help shore up Bankman-Fried‚Äôs other firm, Alameda Research.
But throughout the last three years, Bankman-Fried has maintained his innocence, and he's filed an appeal. A hearing is scheduled for Nov. 4.
Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo spoke with Jonathan Jones, a reporter and producer for the investigative podcast ‚ÄúReveal,‚Äù who spent hours talking to the former CEO, FTX insiders and customers.

item.title: From burnout to brilliance: Amanda Anisimova on how honesty sparked her remarkable revival
item.description:
The American stepped away from the tour in 2023 to address her mental health. This year has been spectacular as she has reached two grand slam finals

There is an air of calm surrounding Amanda Anisimova when she speaks; a palpable sense of her comfort in her own skin.

In a sport like tennis that can swing its protagonists from one emotional extreme to another, week in, week out, Anisimova has worked hard to value the highs, the lows, and the moments in between, all while staying true to herself.

Continue reading...

item.title: At the World Series the Blue Jays belonged to Canada ‚Äì and large parts of the US too
item.description:
One baseball win was never going to bind Canada ‚Äì and sympathetic fans south of the border ‚Äì together for ever. But it was sweet while it lasted

The first time the Blue Jays won a World Series, in 1992, the team‚Äôs victory parade was held on the same day as a contentious national referendum. At play that day was a suite of potential constitutional changes that had Canadians, living through a period of economic strain, regional tension, and a growing distrust of political elites, questioning what kind of country they were living in. The referendum failed and paved the way for another, three years later, in 1995, that almost saw Quebec leave Canada altogether. Following the win, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney congratulated the Jays noting that, beyond it being a ‚Äúhistoric victory‚Äù the team‚Äôs playoff run ‚Äúunited a nation behind you, capturing the imagination of Canadians from coast to coast.‚Äù It was something Canada needed.

This time there was no parade. The Jays lost 5-4 to the LA Dodgers in the early hours of Sunday in a heartbreaking Game 7, missing out on their first World Series title in 32 years.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
One baseball win was never going to bind Canada ‚Äì and sympathetic fans south of the border ‚Äì together for ever. But it was sweet while it lasted
The first time the Blue Jays won a World Series, in 1992, the team‚Äôs victory parade was held on the same day as a contentious national referendum. At play that day was a suite of potential constitutional changes that had Canadians, living through a period of economic strain, regional tension, and a growing distrust of political elites, questioning what kind of country they were living in. The referendum failed and paved the way for another, three years later, in 1995, that almost saw Quebec leave Canada altogether. Following the win, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney congratulated the Jays noting that, beyond it being a ‚Äúhistoric victory‚Äù the team‚Äôs playoff run ‚Äúunited a nation behind you, capturing the imagination of Canadians from coast to coast.‚Äù It was something Canada needed.
This time there was no parade. The Jays lost 5-4 to the LA Dodgers in the early hours of Sunday in [a heartbreaking Game 7](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/nov/02/dodgers-win-world-series-game-7-blue-jays-baseball), missing out on their first World Series title in 32 years.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/nov/03/toronto-blue-jays-world-series)

item.title: The Chiefs-Bills rivalry is incapable of producing a bad game
item.description:
Buffalo extended their regular season domination over Kansas City. But they know that the playoffs are another matter altogether

Of course Josh Allen didn‚Äôt take a breath in the final seconds of the latest Chiefs-Bills classic. ‚ÄúYou never know with Pat [Mahomes],‚Äù Allen told reporters after Buffalo eked out a 28-21 win on Sunday. Bills kicker Matt Prater had earlier missed a 52-yard field goal with 27 seconds remaining that would have sealed the win for Buffalo. Even the miss was dramatic, with Prater doinking his kick off the right upright. Allen wasn‚Äôt alone in thinking Mahomes could lead the Chiefs 58 yards down the field with 22 seconds left and no time outs. One Chiefs fan in Buffalo certainly reminded the home crowd of Buffalo‚Äôs 2021 divisional round collapse in which Mahomes hit Tyreek Hill and then Travis Kelce with 13 seconds remaining to set up a game-tying field goal and eventual overtime win.

Are these two teams capable of a producing a boring contest when they meet? Sunday had looked like it would go down that route, given the statement made by Buffalo‚Äôs defense, before the Chiefs threatened a comeback in the fourth quarter. The Bills had responded to questions about their depleted defense by stymying Mahomes for most of the game. This sandwich sack by Greg Rousseau and Michael Hoecht showed the tenacity of Buffalo‚Äôs defensive line. They needed it: Mahomes converted on fourth and 17 at the beginning of the fourth quarter, a reminder that no matter the situation, he is always capable of tormenting the Bills.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Buffalo extended their regular season domination over Kansas City. But they know that the playoffs are another matter altogether
Of course Josh Allen didn‚Äôt take a breath in the final seconds of the latest Chiefs-Bills classic. ‚ÄúYou never know with Pat \[Mahomes\],‚Äù Allen told reporters after Buffalo eked out a 28-21 win on Sunday. Bills kicker Matt Prater had earlier missed a 52-yard field goal with 27 seconds remaining that would have sealed the win for Buffalo. Even the miss was dramatic, with Prater doinking his kick off the right upright. Allen wasn‚Äôt alone in thinking Mahomes could lead the Chiefs 58 yards down the field with 22 seconds left and no time outs. One Chiefs fan in Buffalo certainly [reminded the home crowd](https://x.com/TrainwreckSprts/status/1985030484615721042) of Buffalo‚Äôs 2021 divisional round collapse in which Mahomes hit Tyreek Hill and then Travis Kelce with 13 seconds remaining to set up a game-tying field goal and eventual overtime win.
Are these two teams capable of a producing a boring contest when they meet? Sunday had looked like it would go down that route, given the statement made by Buffalo‚Äôs defense, before the Chiefs threatened a comeback in the fourth quarter. The Bills had responded to questions about their depleted defense by stymying Mahomes for most of the game. This [sandwich sack](https://x.com/NFL/status/1985126243839488080) by Greg Rousseau and Michael Hoecht showed the tenacity of Buffalo‚Äôs defensive line. They needed it: Mahomes converted on fourth and 17 at the beginning of the fourth quarter, a reminder that no matter the situation, he is always capable of tormenting the Bills.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/nov/03/the-chiefs-bills-rivalry-is-incapable-of-producing-a-bad-game)

item.title: Talking Horses | Willie Mullins eyes Melbourne and Breeders‚Äô Cup double after shock triumph
item.description:
The dominant jumps racing trainer has another huge Flat prize in sight after Ethical Diamond‚Äôs sparkling success

If five wins from the seven turf events, one short of the record, felt like a standard return for European runners at the 2025 Breeders‚Äô Cup at Del Mar, then the identity of the biggest winner of all was a huge, and very refreshing, surprise.

Willie Mullins blew into Del Mar with Ethical Diamond, his first ever runner at the meeting, and left with the $2m first prize in the Turf, nearly five times as much as he banked when Nick Rockett landed the Grand National in April. And the style of his win was equally memorable. Punters who backed the proven Group One form of Minnie Hauk and Rebel‚Äôs Romance might beg to differ, but it gladdened the heart to see an Ebor Handicap winner leave the pair of them standing with a stretch run for the ages.

Continue reading...

item.title: Top 10 US billionaires‚Äô collective wealth grew by $698bn in past year ‚Äì report
item.description:
Oxfam warns Trump policies risk driving inequality to new heights ‚Äì but Democrats have also exacerbated wealth gap

The collective wealth of the top 10 US billionaires has soared by $698bn in the past year, according to a new report from Oxfam America published on Monday on the growing wealth divide.

The report warns that Trump administration policies risk driving US inequality to new heights, but points out that both Republican and Democratic administrations have exacerbated the US‚Äôs growing wealth gap.

Continue reading...

The report warns that [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) policies risk driving US [inequality](https://www.theguardian.com/inequality) to new heights, but points out that both [Republican](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/republicans) and [Democratic](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/democrats) administrations have exacerbated the US‚Äôs growing wealth gap.

President‚Äôs remarks, made during CBS interview released on Sunday, come as the US amasses military units in Caribbean

Donald Trump has sent mixed signals about potential US intervention in Venezuela, playing down concerns of imminent war against the South American nation but saying its leader Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs days were numbered.

The president‚Äôs remarks, made during a CBS interview released on Sunday, come as the US amasses military units in the Caribbean and has conducted multiple strikes on alleged drug-trafficking vessels, killing dozens.

item.title: Russia takes another step toward tightening control of the internet, calling it 'national security'
item.description: The recent introduction of the messaging app Max is the Kremlin's latest effort to tighten control over Russia's digital space by throttling foreign platforms, either by blocking them or slowing them down so they are largely inaccessible. It has drawn immediate comparisons to China's WeChat.
item.source:markdown:
![Starting Sept. 1, all new phones sold in Russia come with the pre-installed Max app, which the government is hoping replaces other popular platforms like Whatsapp.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/693568a1-09d4-4711-9dee-06adda3ebe56,1761836997388/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C240%2C5775%2C3248%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: George Clooney says replacing Joe Biden with Kamala Harris ‚Äòwas a mistake‚Äô
item.description:
Actor says Harris ‚Äòwas given a very tough task‚Äô because ‚Äòshe had to run against her own record‚Äô, and extends an olive branch to Hunter Biden

George Clooney has said he feels it was a ‚Äúmistake‚Äù for Kamala Harris to replace Joe Biden in the 2024 US presidential election, adding that he had no regrets about the New York Times opinion piece in which he called on the Democrats to find a new presidential nominee.

Speaking on CBS‚Äô Sunday Morning, the actor and activist, who is a prominent financial donor to the Democratic party, said he would write his op-ed again if given the chance, and that he wished the Democrats had held a new primary to elect a presidential candidate. Instead, Harris was nominated by a virtual vote of party delegates.

Continue reading...

item.title: Nine people injured in mass shooting at Ohio party held in Airbnb
item.description:
Teenagers had gathered at the house for a birthday party and the motive for the shooting was unclear

Nine people were injured by gunfire early Sunday at a large rental home where teenagers had gathered for a birthday party that was promoted on social media. The scene in north-eastern Ohio was chaotic as some people fled and first responders performed life-saving measures, police said.

The shooting happened at about 12.15am local time in Bath Township, about 15 miles (24 km) north-west of Akron.

Continue reading...

item.title: Two California officers hospitalized after alleged attack by incarcerated man
item.description:
Authorities are investigating the incident as an attempted homicide and suspect was placed in restricted housing

Two California prison officers were hospitalized after an alleged attack by an incarcerated man, and authorities are investigating it as an attempted homicide, officials said Sunday.

The incident happened Saturday at the California state prison in Sacramento as the suspect was being escorted from his cell to allow staff to conduct a search, according to the state department of corrections and rehabilitation.

item.source:markdown:

item.title: FBI fires top official amid Kash Patel‚Äôs outrage over reports of agency jet use
item.description:
Patel reportedly became furious after revelation he flew to visit girlfriend as agency fires official who oversees fleet

A top FBI official with 27 years standing has reportedly been fired by the bureau after its director, Kash Patel, became enraged by press stories revealing he had used a government jet to travel to see his girlfriend sing the national anthem at a wrestling match.

Steven Palmer, who had worked at the bureau since 1998, was fired as head of the FBI‚Äôs critical incident response group which is responsible for handling major security threats as well as overseeing the agency‚Äôs fleet of jets. He was the third head of the unit to be dismissed since Patel became the second Trump administration‚Äôs FBI director in February.

Continue reading...

item.title: Republicans argue ‚Äòbig-hearted president‚Äô Trump is keen to end shutdown
item.description:
House speaker says president has ‚Äòtried everything he can‚Äô even while Trump delays food benefits to millions

Top Republicans are portraying Donald Trump as a ‚Äúbig-hearted president‚Äù who is desperate to reopen the US government, even as he delays food assistance funding for millions of low-income Americans but steams ahead with construction of his $300m gilded White House ballroom.

As the government shutdown entered its 33rd day, the Republican speaker of the House, Mike Johnson, presented Trump as a man angry and desperate to break the impasse so as to ease mounting pain for ordinary Americans. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs just desperate for the government to open, he‚Äôs tried everything he can,‚Äù Johnson said, adding that Trump was a ‚Äúbig-hearted president, he wants everybody to get their services‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.description:
Former president also praises Mamdani‚Äôs campaign against rivals Andrew Cuomo and Curtis Sliwa

Zohran Mamdani, who holds a lead in polling ahead of New York City‚Äôs mayoral election on Tuesday, reportedly received a call on Saturday from his fellow Democrat Barack Obama ‚Äì and the former president offered to be a ‚Äúsounding board‚Äù if his advantage turns into victory.

Obama also praised the campaign Mamdani had run against his main independent rival, former New York governor Andrew Cuomo, and the Republican nominee, Curtis Sliwa.

item.title: Pall of ICE spoils weekend celebrations in Chicago: ‚ÄòI think people are just scared‚Äô
item.description:
Despite Illinois governor‚Äôs plea to let families celebrate Halloween and D√≠a de los Muertos, agents used pepper spray and continued to arrest people

For 40-year-old Cecilia Romero, the days before and after Halloween are not just any other holiday. It‚Äôs the time of year when she can take her kids trick-or-treating in the neighborhood she‚Äôs from ‚Äì and a connection to her own past when she would go celebrate as a little girl.

She remembers years of streets brimming with families and children, with street vendors selling food and cempas√∫chil, the marigolds that loved ones place on altars for Day of the Dead ‚Äì or D√≠a de los Muertos ‚Äì from 1 to 2 November.

item.title: John F Kennedy grandson says Julia Fox‚Äôs bloody Jackie Halloween costume ‚Äòdisgusting‚Äô
item.description:
Jack Schlossberg says ‚Äòdangerous‚Äô to evoke grandfather‚Äôs assassination; Fox says it‚Äôs a ‚Äòstatement‚Äô of Jackie‚Äôs ‚Äòbravery‚Äô

Political writer and commentator Jack Schlossberg has said it was ‚Äúdisgusting, desperate and dangerous‚Äù for actor Julia Fox to wear a Halloween costume evoking the assassination of president John F Kennedy, his grandfather.

Fox, however, has defended her controversial decision to wear a replica of the blood-stained, pink suit that former first lady Jackie Kennedy was seen wearing when her husband was shot dead by a sniper while the couple rode in a motorcade in Dallas in 1963. The Uncut Gems star has said she dressed as Jackie Kennedy as ‚Äúa statement‚Äù about the poise and ‚Äúextraordinary bravery‚Äù she showed when subjected to unimaginable ‚Äúbrutality‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: California set to approve Prop 50 as voters signal displeasure with Trump
item.description:
Voters set to accept new maps to help Democrats counter Republican gerrymandering ‚Äì and check president‚Äôs power

California‚Äôs Proposition 50 began as a warning from the nation‚Äôs largest blue state to its largest red one: don‚Äôt poke the bear. But when Texas moved ahead with a rare, mid-decade gerrymander, pushed by Donald Trump as Republicans seek to shore up their fragile House majority in the midterm elections, California made good on its threat.

Now, California voters appear poised to approve a redistricting measure placed on the ballot in August by Democrats and the state‚Äôs governor, Gavin Newsom, who have cast it as a chance to check Trump‚Äôs power.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Voters set to accept new maps to help Democrats counter Republican gerrymandering ‚Äì and check president‚Äôs power

But when Texas [moved ahead](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/18/texas-democrats-california-electoral-maps-redistricting) with a rare, mid-decade gerrymander, pushed by Donald Trump as Republicans seek to shore up their fragile House majority in the midterm elections, California made good on its threat.
Now, California voters appear poised to approve a redistricting measure placed on the ballot in August by Democrats and the state‚Äôs governor, [Gavin Newsom](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/gavin-newsom), who have cast it as a chance [to check Trump‚Äôs power](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/25/california-prop-50-trump-redistricting).

The Democratic candidate for governor of Virginia, Abigail Spanberger, pitched her closing argument on Saturday to more than 7,000 supporters at a campaign rally in Norfolk, home to the world‚Äôs biggest naval base.

item.title: If the Dodgers are bad for baseball, why was the World Series so much fun?
item.description:
The repeat champions‚Äô vast wealth means they can stockpile talent unimaginable to other teams. But it‚Äôs undeniable that the results are hugely entertaining

A unicorn led off the game with a single and then trotted out to the mound to pitch the bottom of the first. Another pitcher won Games 2, 6, and 7 of the World Series, throwing 17.2 innings along the way. A catcher set a record, squatting behind the plate for 74 Fall Classic frames and ultimately ended the series by hitting the final go-ahead home run.

Just as everyone feared or sneered, the Los Angeles Dodgers are champions. Again. In what some forecasted as a harbinger of doom, the sinister strategy of employing the best baseball player on the planet along with a generous number of his nearly equal peers proved effective. It‚Äôs not fair, some people will say in the coming months about the fact that the team broadly believed to be the best ultimately won it all.

Continue reading...

item.title: Hiking with the wildlife author who studies Yosemite‚Äôs high peaks: ‚ÄòThese animals are equal to us‚Äô
item.description:
Inspired by childhood encyclopedias and Jane Goodall, Beth Pratt writes about the more than 150 species in the national park ‚Äì and transports readers to a rarefied world

A shrill call was followed by a flash of movement through a pile of boulders on a high country slope in Yosemite national park. ‚ÄúHello, Sophie!‚Äù Beth Pratt responded to the round, feisty pika who had briefly emerged to pose defiantly in the sun.

Pratt, a conservation leader and wildlife advocate, has spent more than a decade observing the tiny mammals and the other inhabitants of these serene granite domes and the alpine meadows they overlook, which gleamed gold on a crisp afternoon in mid-October.

Continue reading...

item.title: Blue Jays reflect on cruel Game 7 loss to Dodgers: ‚ÄòI cost everybody a World Series‚Äô
item.description:
• Toronto miss out on first World Series title since 1993

  • Blue Jays held lead going into ninth inning

The Toronto Blue Jays have reflected on their agonizing loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers in Game 7 of the World Series.

The Blue Jays looked set to win their first World Series since 1993 when they entered the ninth inning with a 4-3 lead. But with one out, and Toronto‚Äôs Jeff Hoffman facing the Dodgers‚Äô No 9 hitter, Miguel Rojas, the reliever threw a hanging slider which Rojas launched for the tying home run. Will Smith then hit the winning home run in the 11th inning off Shane Bieber, the first time the Dodgers had led all night.

Continue reading...

Will Smith then hit the winning home run in the 11th inning off Shane Bieber, the first time the Dodgers had led all night.

item.title: The president who cried tariffs: will the US supreme court challenge Trump‚Äôs trade war?
item.description:
The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump‚Äôs erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally valid

Donald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an ‚Äúinvasion‚Äù of ‚Äúillegal aliens‚Äù from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.

Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy ‚Äì tariffs ‚Äì is legally valid.

Continue reading...

item.title: America‚Äôs redistricting fight: how could the US congressional map shift?
item.description:
Republicans hold a 219-213 majority in the House, but they could lock in more seats if reapportionments go their way

Republicans and Democrats have entered a war in legislatures and courts to narrow the political battlefield of 2026 before a single vote is cast.

Normally, redistricting only occurs after the US census counts residents in each state every 10 years. A demand from Donald Trump to lock in more Republican-leaning districts in Congress, together with a changing legal landscape around partisan gerrymandering, set off a chain of mid-decade reapportionments.

Continue reading...
